required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Randomized Control Trial Comparing Prokinetics and Their Influence on Endoscopy Outcomes for Upper GI Bleed.
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Control Trial Comparing Prokinetics and Their Influence on Endoscopy Outcomes for Upper GI Bleed.

lead_sponsor.agency: Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, El Paso

clinical_study.source: Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, El Paso

brief_summary.textblock: This is a study comparing the effect of erythromycin or metoclopramide, 2 prokinetic drugs (Drugs which are known to speed up the emptying of the stomach or in other words to move the blood out of the stomach faster) given before endoscopy to patients with upper Gastrointestinal bleeding compared to patients who will not receive either of these medications before their endoscopy.

detailed_description.textblock:
To compare the efficacy of pre-endoscopic interventions namely erythromycin, metoclopromide vs control in improving the outcomes of endoscopy in ICU patients admitted upper GI bleeding.
Specific aims:
1. Wither erythromycin, metoclopromide vs control can enable visualization of the entire gastric mucosa .
2. Wither erythromycin, metoclopromide vs control can improve the quality of stomach and duodenum visualization: using the scoring system by Fossard et al

primary_outcome.measure: Erythromycin, Metoclopromide vs Control Enabling Visualization of the Entire Gastric Mucosa .
primary_outcome.description: Whether erythromycin, metoclopramide versus control can enable visualization of the entire gastric mucosa .

primary_outcome.measure: Erythromycin, Metoclopromide vs Control Improving the Quality of Stomach and Duodenum Visualization
primary_outcome.description: Whether erythromycin, metoclopramide vs control can improve the quality of stomach and duodenum visualization: using the scoring system by Fossard et al

secondary_outcome.description: Ability to identify the source of bleeding
Mean number of blood units transfused

arm_group.description: Intravenous erythromycin infusion (dose: 250 mg) 30 min-60 min before procedure
Intravenous metoclopromide infusion (dose: 10 mg) 30-60 minutes prior to endoscopy
no medications will be given prior to endoscopy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients (18-80)
- who are admitted to the ICU for hematemesis, or coffee ground emesis
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients younger than 18 yrs old or older than 80 yrs
2. Patients who refuse to consent to be in our study
3. Pregnant patients
4. Prior use of prokinetics in the last 48 hours
5. History of cardiac arrhythmia
6. Allergy to erythromycin or metoclopromide
7. Patients with QT prolongation (query 7)
-
